1895-09-17 00:10:00 Magnus Mulberrylane -- Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Magnus Mulberrylane's attempted action: 4 coins
    Active player
  • Magnus Mulberrylane
      Name
    • Magnus Mulberrylane
      Action attempt
    • 4 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Magnus Mulberrylane are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Magnus Mulberrylane. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Magnus Mulberrylane as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Magnus Mulberrylane would respond, and taking into account all information about Magnus Mulberrylane that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is 32 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane



          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Question: What price would Magnus Mulberrylane propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 1 coin
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (b)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Magnus Mulberrylane are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Magnus Mulberrylane. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Magnus Mulberrylane as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Magnus Mulberrylane would respond, and taking into account all information about Magnus Mulberrylane that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Magnus Mulberrylane:
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Five coins a bushel is a bit steep, Hazel. Say, how about four and a half?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four and a half? I haven't even started breakfast yet, Mr. Mulberrylane. While you may think that's a good deal, five is the bare minimum for this fine quality fruit."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane and Hazel Nutgrove agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Magnus Mulberrylane stands to lose -0.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Three coins a piece, and it's a deal."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two coins apiece, and that's a generous offer."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane accepts the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Magnus Mulberrylane agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Magnus Mulberrylane stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong declines Nutgrove's offer, stating, "Three coins a piece is a bit steep, even for this fine fruit. I'll offer you two and a half, and that's my best."
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Two and a half coins a piece is my bottom line, Aiden. I can't go any lower."
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's a generous offer."
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins? For this fine collection? Hazel, you know my pockets aren't bottomless, but I wouldn't dream of undercutting a fellow Fruitville trader. Allow me to offer you two and a half."
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane

      Payoffs

      Magnus Mulberrylane: 2.0
      Hazel Nutgrove: 3.0
      Joint action
    • {'Magnus Mulberrylane': '4 coins', 'Hazel Nutgrove': 'accept'}

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Magnus Mulberrylane. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two coins? You think these beauties are worth that little? Son, I've traveled far for these, and they deserve a proper premium. Five coins, and we have a deal."
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is my final offer. Those fruits look fine, but not five-coin fine."
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [scene type] day
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins and a half, then. It's a fair price, wouldn't you say?"
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Four and a half coins? That's pushing it, old bean, but perhaps... I'll reluctantly concede."
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "These fruits look fine, Hazel. But I'm on a tight budget this trip. Tell ya what, I'll give you 3 coins for the lot."
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins? Those are fine fruits, Aiden, but I reckon they're worth at least five."

It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [scene type] day
[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Five coins is a fair price for these beauties, Aiden. They are ripe and ready to eat, you see."
[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Alright Hazel, I'll give you four coins. But that's my final offer."

[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Magnus Mulberrylane. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Five coins a bushel is a bit steep, Hazel. Say, how about four and a half?"
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four and a half? I haven't even started breakfast yet, Mr. Mulberrylane. While you may think that's a good deal, five is the bare minimum for this fine quality fruit."

[16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Two and a half coins a piece is my bottom line, Aiden. I can't go any lower."
[16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong declines Nutgrove's offer, stating, "Three coins a piece is a bit steep, even for this fine fruit. I'll offer you two and a half, and that's my best."

[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's a generous offer."
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins? For this fine collection? Hazel, you know my pockets aren't bottomless, but I wouldn't dream of undercutting a fellow Fruitville trader. Allow me to offer you two and a half."
